Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: MAKER: Developing Digital Makers in the Coding Makerspace to Include Boys of Color in Computer Science Learning and Cybersecurity Workforce Development

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM). The Coding Makerspace is providing hands-on digital maker projects and support for boys of color to earn certification in Python, the computer programming language related to cybersecurity. The Makerspace is also exposing boys of color ages eight and above to research-based and best practices in computing and cybersecurity education. Additionally, the Makerspace is collaborating with local cyber security companies to gain real-world experience through shadowing and/or field placement opportunities. As a result, the Makerspace is addressing the longstanding underrepresentation of racially diverse students in computer science and increasing their interest in cybersecurity opportunities in higher education, employment, and entrepreneurship.

The Coding Makerspace has great potential to advance knowledge on ways to achieve the goals of equity, diversity, access, and inclusion of racially diverse students in computer science education. The Makerspace is providing boys of color with that support to be creators, not consumers, of computing and cybersecurity innovations that will contribute to society. The project is also facilitating the development of new knowledge on how to broaden the impact of the hands-on computer science education needed to increase racially diverse student interest and cybersecurity workforce preparation. In addition, the Makerspace is addressing the increasing need for all students, particularly underrepresented young men of color, to prepare for the expected growth of cybersecurity jobs that protects the country's national security.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The MBK Coding Makerspace project was appropriate for EAGER because it was a high risk model that had high reward and great potential benefit to advance knowledge on ways to achieve the goals of equity, diversity, access, and inclusion of boys of color in STEM and computer science education. The MBK Coding Makerspace was of high reward because it responded to the Nation's goals to create Makerspace learning models that include boys of color as digital makers and future leaders in computing careers. The gains were significant in the project because it helped us create knowledge about gender specific ways to broaden participation in STEM and computer science. The Makerspace project focused on using computer technology to help boys of color learn to be creators of computing and cybersecurity innovations that will contribute to society rather than just consumers of technology.

Through the MBK Coding Makerspace project, new knowledge was created on how to engage African-American and Hispanic boys with the hands-on computer science education needed to increase their interest/awareness of educational opportunities. The MBK Coding Makerspace also provided boys of color with employment opportunities through the provision workforce development activities (e.g., employment skills and resume preparation) needed to secure employment in computer science careers such as cybersecurity. Since boys of color are facing some of the most severe challenges in the 21st century, the MBK Coding Makerspace focused on providing them with the opportunity to learn digital making and computer science, to create a pathway in the cybersecurity workforce, and to lay a foundation for a computing career. The MBK Coding Makerspace addressed the increasing need to prepare students of color for the expected growth of computing jobs and addressed the need to protect the country's national security through cybersecurity education.

Students who participated in the MBK Coding Makerspace gained computer programming experience, professional development, and workforce preparation. Students completed a Udemy course in Python, a resume, and received direction pertaining to online certification programs.  Informal support networks, friendships, alliances are a by product of this experience. This is significant as most of the students did not know each other prior to attending the program and do not attend the same high school. Researchers found that weekly programming helps to reinforce what students have learned in both formal and informal learning experiences.

The MBK Coding Makerspace aimed to influence greater intentions to persist in computing while affirming students' growth mindset (effort), in addition to their abilities. Students who participated in the MBK Coding Makerspace program saw their hard work as being a part of learning, rather than a way to evaluate self-worth or assess sense of belonging. In year two, the MBK Coding Makerspace evolved to develop digital making projects that were Internet of Things (IoT) home automation projects reflecting the students experiences and cultures. The digital making projects were designed to solve problems in the students home, schools, and communities while integrating cybersecurity skills.  The students received exposure to coding and hardware design concepts using the Raspberry Pi and applied learned information to hands-on projects in an aim to develop a digital portfolio and improve keyboarding skills. In addition, the MBK Coding Makerspace increased attitudes towards computing, which lead to greater intentions to persist in computing.
